items.title: Knife Slits Water
items.content_html: “Martha Tilson: Knife Slits Water is about sex, plain and simple - but also desire and sexual politics. The day the music was recorded I wasn’t feeling well and had skipped the studio session. Jez and Pete came back to our flat with a cassette, we were all really excited by it. A day or so later, at the mixing session, the line “Who sold that knife to me?” came to me. I think I then wrote the rest of the lyrics in an hour or so. The title came later, and is sort of influenced by Roman Polanski’s Knife in the Water. I think it makes most sense when a woman sings it. It’s tougher then, but Donald’s later version was great.”
items.content_text: "Martha Tilson: Knife Slits Water is about sex, plain and simple - but also desire and sexual politics. The day the music was recorded I wasn't feeling well and had skipped the studio session. Jez and Pete came back to our flat with a cassette, we were all really excited by it. A day or so later, at the mixing session, the line "Who sold that knife to me?" came to me. I think I then wrote the rest of the lyrics in an hour or so. The title came later, and is sort of influenced by Roman Polanski's Knife in the Water. I think it makes most sense when a woman sings it. It's tougher then, but Donald's later version was great."

items.title: Skate Flyers from Mid 2000s
items.content_html:
I landed on Wayback Machine Downloader today so I downloaded the archives of a design website I had from 2002-2011. Came across a couple of flyers that I made for a bunch of us old skaters that wanted to be their younger selves. These events were almost 20 years ago! We were old then so that must make us positively ancient now …

#skate #skateboarding #skatopia #socal
items.content_text: I landed on [Wayback Machine Downloader](https://github.com/hartator/wayback-machine-downloader) today so I downloaded the archives of a design website I had from 2002-2011. Came across a couple of flyers that I made for a bunch of us old skaters that wanted to be their younger selves. These events were almost 20 years ago! We were old then so that must make us positively ancient now ... #skate #skateboarding #skatopia #socal

items.content_html:
In music 🎵 as well as books 📚I tend to follow a lot of paths. 📷

Bukowski -> Black Sparrow Press -> Paul Bowles -> Mohammed Mrabet.

Ultravox cover of “King’s Lead Hat” at the Whiskey in 1979 -> Brian Eno -> Eno/Byrne -> Amos Tutola.
items.content_text: In music 🎵 as well as books 📚I tend to follow a lot of paths. 📷 Bukowski -> Black Sparrow Press -> Paul Bowles -> Mohammed Mrabet. Ultravox cover of "King's Lead Hat" at the Whiskey in 1979 -> Brian Eno -> Eno/Byrne -> Amos Tutola.

Currently into the 2nd volume of this Memoir from [Loyal Books](https://www.loyalbooks.com/book/memoirs-of-a-revolutionist-vol-2-by-peter-kropotkin).

With 18 hours a week in commute to work and various responsibilities a week I've been getting kinda sick of some podcasts.

items.content_html: There is a small beach north of us where we, one day, found hundreds of apples all over the sand. There are some orchards nearby where we get fancy apples by the pound. I don’t remember a large storm near then but how else would they get from the orchards to the ocean to the beach? 📷

items.content_html:
A. R. Moxon is always spot on.

Questions for Substack

…It also suggests that what Nazis have are “ideas,” when we know that what they actually have are intentions, and those intentions always create real-life violence toward marginalized communities along racial, ethnic, religious, and other lines of bigotry—and they do so the more effectively Nazis are able to gather and organize and promote their “ideas” into the mainstream.
items.content_text:
A. R. Moxon is always spot on.

 [Questions for Substack](https://armoxon.substack.com/p/questions-for-substack)

> ...It also suggests that what Nazis have are “ideas,” when we know that what they actually have are intentions, and those intentions always create real-life violence toward marginalized communities along racial, ethnic, religious, and other lines of bigotry—and they do so the more effectively Nazis are able to gather and organize and promote their “ideas” into the mainstream.

items.content_html:
No, what you do is not sell AI images for photo journalism.

Adobe Stock is Selling AI-Generated Images of the Israel-Hamas Conflict

“Adobe is committed to fighting misinformation, and via the Content Authenticity Initiative, we are working with publishers, camera manufacturers and other stakeholders to advance the adoption of Content Credentials, including in our own products. Content Credentials allows people to see vital context about how a piece of digital content was captured, created or edited including whether AI tools were used in the creation or editing of the digital content.”
items.content_text:
No, what you do is not sell AI images for photo journalism. 

[Adobe Stock is Selling AI-Generated Images of the Israel-Hamas Conflict](https://petapixel.com/2023/11/07/adobe-stock-is-selling-ai-generated-images-of-the-israel-hamas-conflict/)

> “Adobe is committed to fighting misinformation, and via the Content Authenticity Initiative, we are working with publishers, camera manufacturers and other stakeholders to advance the adoption of Content Credentials, including in our own products. Content Credentials allows people to see vital context about how a piece of digital content was captured, created or edited including whether AI tools were used in the creation or editing of the digital content.”

items.content_html:
I’m transitioning over to the POSSE form of publishing.

I’ll be writing all of my posts at mico.blog which will post to What Shall We Do Without Us? with photos getting pushed to pixelfed. Some small things might end up on Bluesky.

So there, now, this is it.
items.content_text:
I'm transitioning over to the [POSSE](https://indieweb.org/POSSE) form of publishing.

I'll be writing all of my posts at [mico.blog](https://aloysiusbest.micro.blog/) which will post to [What Shall We Do Without Us?](https://whatshallwedowithout.us/@toby) with photos getting pushed to [pixelfed](https://pixelfed.social/i/web/profile/497826620802348131). Some small things might end up on [Bluesky](https://bsky.app/profile/aloysius.best).

So there, now, this is it.

items.content_html: The only true Beat. From and for the people. I have so much respect for Bob Kaufman.
items.content_text: The only true *Beat*. From and for the people. I have so much respect for Bob Kaufman.

items.content_html:
This is a wonderful book. While lucid dreaming is a very interesting topic, I keep returning to the book’s intentions. Truly beautiful.

Sleep, Death’s Brother is an instruction manual on dreaming that is intended for children or incarcerated persons. It enables such individuals to learn to lucid dream and to use their dreams to somewhat escape their situations.

— From Pioneer Works
items.content_text: This is a wonderful book. While lucid dreaming is a very interesting topic, I keep returning to the book’s intentions. Truly beautiful. > *Sleep, Death’s Brother* is an instruction manual on dreaming that is intended for children or incarcerated persons. It enables such individuals to learn to lucid dream and to use their dreams to somewhat escape their situations. > > — From [Pioneer Works](https://pioneerworks.org/publishing/jesse-ball-sleep-deaths-brother/)

items.title: Reading Albion's Journal
items.content_html:
Reading Albion’s Journal

I read The Journal of Albion Moonlight by Kenneth Patchen a long time ago. I’ve had an idea to write a daily reflection on each of these journal entries on the day of the year that they occurred. This summer is the time.

The journal is written from May 2nd to August 27th. I’m feeling a kinship with Albion Moonlight with this plague summer that we are starting in 2019. While the past 2+ years here in the United States of America cannot compare to World War 2…We are rapidly spiraling out of control with the dismantling of our democracy by the Trump administration and Republican complicity in these actions.
items.content_text: [Reading Albion's Journal](https://readingalbionsjournal.com) I read [The Journal of Albion Moonlight](https://www.ndbooks.com/book/the-journal-of-albion-moonlight/) by [Kenneth Patchen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_Patchen) a long time ago. I’ve had an idea to write a daily reflection on each of these journal entries on the day of the year that they occurred. This summer is the time. The journal is written from May 2nd to August 27th. I’m feeling a kinship with Albion Moonlight with this plague summer that we are starting in 2019. While the past 2+ years here in the United States of America cannot compare to World War 2…We are rapidly spiraling out of control with the dismantling of our democracy by the Trump administration and Republican complicity in these actions.

items.content_html:
Don’t be nervous. Work calmly, joyously, recklessly on whatever is in hand.

— Henry Miller from Brainpickings

items.content_html:
I also like to read difficult things that don’t say much to me, just to be in something difficult. Now, for instance, I’m reading about chemistry. I don’t know anything about chemistry, and that’s a comfort. The same with reading Heidegger, it’s also completely incomprehensible but it’s still something … I like being in that

— Karl Ove Knausgaard in the LA Review of Books

This made me laugh because I can completely relate to reading in this way some times. I let most of A New Kind of Science by Stephen Wolfram just roll right on by me for an inordinate amount of time when it came out.
items.content_text:
> I also like to read difficult things that don’t say much to me, just to  be in something difficult. Now, for instance, I’m reading about chemistry. I don’t know anything about chemistry, and that’s a comfort. The same with reading Heidegger, it’s also completely incomprehensible but it’s still something … I like being in that
>
> — Karl Ove Knausgaard in the [LA Review of Books](https://lareviewofbooks.org/article/karl-ove-knausgaard) 

This made me laugh because I can completely relate to reading in this way some times. I let most of [A New Kind of Science](https://www.wolframscience.com/nks/) by Stephen Wolfram just roll right on by me for an inordinate amount of time when it came out.
